title: A Year in Procurement Stories: Looking Back on Q1
description:
With 10 million social enterprises globally generating US$2tn annually, the message was clear: procurement professionals hold considerable power in directing resources toward equitable outcomes.
The bottleneck revealed a fundamental procurement challenge – securing diverse, sustainable feedstock whilst building logistics networks capable of supporting global distribution.
Houthi attacks in the Red Sea forced shipping companies to reroute vessels around Africa's Cape of Good Hope, avoiding the Suez Canal entirely.
The crisis sent shipping rates soaring and forced businesses relying on just-in-time manufacturing to reconsider fundamental assumptions about supply chain design.
If the Red Sea crisis tested maritime logistics, infrastructure vulnerability exposed different weaknesses.
text:
The first quarter of 2025 unfolded as a defining period for global procurement – marked by competing priorities of equity and efficiency, regulatory upheaval and resilience tests that challenged even the most prepared organisations.

The conversation began with vision. The World Economic Forum, alongside Deloitte and the Schwab Foundation, released research spotlighting equity's role in green and digital transformation.

WEF: The Role of Equity in Green & Digital Transformation

The report emphasised that social enterprises – businesses prioritising impact over profit – could be instrumental in ensuring inclusive growth during these transitions. With 10 million social enterprises globally generating US$2tn annually, the message was clear: procurement professionals hold considerable power in directing resources toward equitable outcomes.

Yet vision alone wouldn't sustain progress. The aviation sector grappled with translating sustainable ambitions into operational reality as sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) confronted scaling challenges.

Can Aviation Overcome SAF Scaling and Cost Challenges?

Despite offering an 80% reduction in lifecycle emissions, SAF production remained hampered by feedstock scarcity, concentrated production facilities and costs exceeding traditional jet fuel.

Marie Owens Thomsen, IATA's Senior Vice President of Sustainability, articulated the urgency: "We need the whole world to produce as much renewable energy as possible for everybody. Airlines simply want to access their fair share of that output."

The bottleneck revealed a fundamental procurement challenge – securing diverse, sustainable feedstock whilst building logistics networks capable of supporting global distribution.

Meanwhile, businesses faced more immediate concerns as political transitions reshaped cost structures. When President Donald Trump took office, proposed tariffs on imports from Canada and Mexico threatened to raise US grocery prices and disrupt established sourcing strategies.

How Costco Wholesale Will Deal With Tariffs Uncertainty

Costco's response illustrated pragmatic procurement leadership.

CFO Gary Millerchip acknowledged the challenge candidly: "Tariffs raise costs so that's not something that we see as a positive in general."

Yet the company's approach – pulling forward inventory, working with vendors to mitigate costs, exploring alternative sourcing locations and pivoting SKUs when value disappeared – demonstrated how experienced procurement teams navigate policy uncertainty.

His predecessor's wisdom echoed through the strategy: "When it rains, it rains on everybody."

Andreas Rasche, Professor at Copenhagen Business School, expressed concern: "This is very disappointing and not at all proportionate. The document gives no evidence-based reasons for the changes."

For procurement teams, the implications were significant – reduced access to sustainability data could create blind spots in responsible sourcing efforts, particularly in complex global networks.

Regulatory upheaval wasn't confined to Brussels. In the UK, plans to abolish NHS England and integrate its functions into the Department of Health marked a pivotal shift in healthcare procurement.

NHS England Reform: What Does It Mean for Procurement?

Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer positioned the move as streamlining administration, yet the restructuring threatened to disrupt ongoing procurement reforms and delay purchasing of essential medicines and medical devices.

With approximately 9,000 job losses expected and a £7bn deficit to manage, procurement teams faced budgetary constraints whilst navigating decentralised decision-making through local Integrated Care Boards. The challenge became clear: achieving efficiency improvements without undermining supplier relationships or equitable patient care.

Beyond regulatory shifts, physical disruptions tested supply chain resilience. Houthi attacks in the Red Sea forced shipping companies to reroute vessels around Africa's Cape of Good Hope, avoiding the Suez Canal entirely.

How the Shipping Crisis in the Red Sea is Impacting Trade

Container shipments through the region dropped 75% as companies navigated the trade-off between security risks and the costs of detours adding 10 to 14 days to transit times.

Xeneta's Chief Analyst Peter Sand stated: "All ships transiting the Suez Canal must sail through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden and the Houthi militia has made clear that any vessel is a target."

The crisis sent shipping rates soaring and forced businesses relying on just-in-time manufacturing to reconsider fundamental assumptions about supply chain design.

If the Red Sea crisis tested maritime logistics, infrastructure vulnerability exposed different weaknesses. A fire at an electrical substation forced Heathrow Airport's closure until midnight on 21 March, affecting more than 1,300 flights.

How the Heathrow Airport Closure Impacted Supply Chains

The incident disrupted not just passenger travel but cargo operations at the UK's largest port by value, handling more than 1.6 million metric tonnes of freight annually.

John Manners-Bell, CEO of Transport Intelligence, criticised the apparent oversight: "A fire at a single power sub-station bringing one of the world's busiest airports to a complete halt? Someone has been asleep at the wheel."

The event served as a stark reminder that even the most sophisticated supply chains remain vulnerable to infrastructure failures beyond procurement's direct control.

These individual disruptions converged into a broader pattern. QIMA's 2025 Sourcing Survey revealed that three-quarters of businesses expected supply chain disruptions to persist, whilst nearly 90% still lacked full visibility into their supply chains.

Businesses Dealing with Escalating Supply Chain Disruptions

Companies responded by diversifying sourcing strategies – two-thirds maintained or expanded Chinese supplier operations whilst half of US businesses shifted volumes closer to home through nearshoring.

title: Queenstown Joins Auckland, Wellington, Rarotonga, and More in Air New Zealand's 2026 ...
description:
Image Source: Air New Zealand Air New Zealand is set to make a huge impact on tourism in 2026 with its exciting route expansion.
Queenstown joins Auckland, Wellington, Rarotonga, and more in this new network, boosting access to New Zealand’s iconic destinations and the Pacific Islands.
Air New Zealand’s expanded route from Brisbane to Wellington is another fantastic way for travelers to explore this charming city.
Enhanced Route: Brisbane ↔ Wellington Route Type: Seasonal Capacity Increase Start Date: 2026 Key Features: Wellington is famous for its picturesque harbor and vibrant arts scene.
New Seasonal Route: Christchurch ↔ Rarotonga Route Type: Seasonal Non-Stop Flight Start Date: May 2026 End Date: October 2026 Key Features: Rarotonga is a dream destination for those looking for a tropical escape.
text:
Image Source: Air New Zealand

Air New Zealand is set to make a huge impact on tourism in 2026 with its exciting route expansion. Queenstown joins Auckland, Wellington, Rarotonga, and more in this new network, boosting access to New Zealand’s iconic destinations and the Pacific Islands. This expansion will make it easier for travelers to explore the breathtaking landscapes of Queenstown, the vibrant culture of Auckland, the beautiful waterfront of Wellington, and the tropical paradise of Rarotonga. Air New Zealand’s strategic routes aim to turbocharge tourism, making these incredible destinations more accessible than ever before. By enhancing connectivity between Australia, New Zealand, and the Pacific, this expansion promises to open up new opportunities for travelers, businesses, and local economies alike. Whether seeking adventure, relaxation, or culture, this route network will undoubtedly draw more visitors to these remarkable locations.

Queenstown: A Thrilling Destination Now Within Reach

Queenstown, the adventure capital of New Zealand, is known for its breathtaking scenery, ski resorts, and outdoor activities. This beautiful town on the South Island of New Zealand is now more accessible than ever, thanks to Air New Zealand’s new seasonal route between Brisbane and Queenstown. This flight, which starts in June 2026, offers travelers a chance to experience Queenstown’s stunning landscapes without the hassle of long travel times.

New Seasonal Route: Brisbane ↔ Queenstown

Route Type: Seasonal Non-Stop Flight

Start Date: June 22, 2026

End Date: October 23, 2026

Key Features: Air New Zealand’s new direct flight reduces travel time and offers easy access to Queenstown’s ski fields, vineyards, and adventure tourism options. For outdoor enthusiasts, Queenstown offers skiing, bungee jumping, hiking, and skydiving, making it a must-visit destination.

The route also boosts tourism in Queenstown, helping travelers from Australia access the iconic New Zealand destination for the winter season. This service will make exploring Queenstown even easier, allowing travelers to experience the spectacular alpine views and world-class adventure activities.

Auckland: New Connectivity with Brisbane

Auckland, New Zealand’s largest city, is a hub of culture, commerce, and cuisine. Air New Zealand is ramping up its services from Brisbane to Auckland with an increase in capacity for flights between these two vibrant cities. The additional flights provide more opportunities for business travelers and tourists alike to visit this exciting destination.

Increased Capacity: Brisbane ↔ Auckland

Route Type: Increased Frequency and Capacity

Start Date: 2026 (Peak Season)

Key Features: The increased capacity between Brisbane and Auckland helps meet the rising demand for this popular route. Auckland offers a variety of activities, from visiting the famous Sky Tower to experiencing the vibrant waterfront. Visitors can explore Auckland’s thriving arts scene, lush parks, and multicultural dining experiences.

The added flights will make it easier for travelers to access Auckland’s beaches, nature reserves, and world-class shopping districts. Whether you are in Auckland for business or leisure, the enhanced flight schedule will provide flexibility and convenience.

Wellington: New Flights from Brisbane to New Zealand’s Capital

Wellington, the capital city of New Zealand, is known for its rich cultural heritage, stunning waterfront, and scenic hills. Air New Zealand’s expanded route from Brisbane to Wellington is another fantastic way for travelers to explore this charming city.

Enhanced Route: Brisbane ↔ Wellington

Route Type: Seasonal Capacity Increase

Start Date: 2026

Key Features: Wellington is famous for its picturesque harbor and vibrant arts scene. It is the perfect place to discover New Zealand’s history, culture, and natural beauty. The increased flights between Brisbane and Wellington will help boost tourism, making it easier for travelers to visit museums, dine in exceptional restaurants, and enjoy the city’s famous festivals and events.

Wellington’s unique location, nestled between mountains and the sea, offers breathtaking views at every turn. The new flight capacity will allow more visitors to experience the charm of New Zealand’s capital.

Christchurch: Gateway to the Southern Alps and Beyond

Christchurch, known as the “Garden City,” is located on the South Island of New Zealand. With its proximity to the Southern Alps and Canterbury Plains, Christchurch is the gateway to adventure tourism. Air New Zealand’s new seasonal route from Christchurch to Rarotonga will provide even more opportunities to explore this unique destination.

New Seasonal Route: Christchurch ↔ Rarotonga

Route Type: Seasonal Non-Stop Flight

Start Date: May 2026

End Date: October 2026

Key Features: Christchurch is not just a gateway to adventure; it is also known for its beautiful gardens and public spaces. The new Christchurch-Rarotonga flight connects the South Island to one of the most beautiful tropical islands in the Pacific. Rarotonga, with its turquoise lagoons and white-sand beaches, is a paradise for beach lovers and those looking to relax in a serene environment.

This route is ideal for those looking to combine the cultural experiences of New Zealand with the tranquility of the Cook Islands. The new service will offer easier access to both regions, allowing for a unique vacation experience that mixes adventure and relaxation.

Rarotonga: A Tropical Paradise Awaiting Discovery

Rarotonga, the largest of the Cook Islands, is a beautiful tropical island that offers an idyllic getaway. The new seasonal flight from Christchurch to Rarotonga will make it easier for travelers to access this stunning destination, known for its crystal-clear waters, vibrant coral reefs, and rich Polynesian culture.

New Seasonal Route: Christchurch ↔ Rarotonga

Route Type: Seasonal Non-Stop Flight

Start Date: May 2026

End Date: October 2026

Key Features: Rarotonga is a dream destination for those looking for a tropical escape. The island is famous for its coral reefs, beautiful beaches, and outdoor activities such as snorkeling, hiking, and cultural tours. The new flight from Christchurch opens up this paradise to more travelers, giving them the opportunity to explore one of the most pristine islands in the Pacific.

With its easy access via Christchurch, Rarotonga is set to become even more popular with both Kiwi travelers and those from further afield.

How Air New Zealand’s New Routes Will Transform Travel

Air New Zealand’s new and expanded routes are not just about increasing convenience for travelers – they are also about opening up new opportunities for tourism, business, and cultural exchange between New Zealand, Australia, and the Pacific Islands. Each new route brings with it the potential for enhanced connectivity, increased tourism, and better access to some of the most beautiful and vibrant regions in the Southern Hemisphere.

Table: Summary of New Routes by Air New Zealand

The Economic Impact of Air New Zealand’s New Routes

One of the most significant aspects of Air New Zealand’s route expansion is its economic impact on both New Zealand and Australia. New routes generally bring an increase in tourism, which boosts local businesses, job creation, and infrastructure growth.

For Queenstown, the new seasonal route from Brisbane not only makes it more accessible for adventure tourists but also enhances local employment in the tourism and hospitality sectors. Air New Zealand’s additional capacity on routes between Brisbane and Auckland, Wellington, and Christchurch opens up more opportunities for international business travelers, fostering cross-border trade and collaboration.

The addition of the Christchurch ↔ Rarotonga seasonal flight will stimulate growth in the Pacific Islands tourism sector as well, bringing more travelers to Rarotonga and enhancing connections between New Zealand and the Cook Islands. This will also foster more cultural exchanges and increase awareness of Pacific Island tourism globally.

Sustainability and Air New Zealand’s Commitment to the Environment

Air New Zealand is renowned for its commitment to sustainability and reducing its carbon footprint. With the addition of these new routes, the airline is working hard to implement eco-friendly initiatives to ensure the growth of air travel is balanced with environmental responsibility.

These efforts include:

Sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), which reduces carbon emissions from flights.

More fuel-efficient aircraft, which Air New Zealand has been integrating into its fleet over recent years.

Carbon offset programs, allowing passengers to voluntarily offset their travel-related carbon emissions.

Through these sustainability measures, Air New Zealand is not only enhancing connectivity but also contributing to the broader effort to make air travel more environmentally conscious.

Traveler Tips: Making the Most of These New Routes

With the launch of these new routes, it’s important for travelers to take full advantage of the opportunity. Here are some tips to make the most out of Air New Zealand’s new services:

Book Early for Best Prices: Air New Zealand typically offers the best deals for early bookings. Take advantage of this to save money on your flight.

Explore New Destinations: With these new routes, travelers now have the chance to experience Queenstown’s adventure tourism, Auckland’s thriving city life, and Rarotonga’s tropical beauty in a more convenient and affordable way.

Take Advantage of Air New Zealand’s Loyalty Programs: Travelers can benefit from the airline’s Frequent Flyer Program, which offers points and rewards for frequent travelers.

Connect with Local Activities: Once at your destination, make sure to explore not only the popular tourist spots but also local hidden gems. For example, in Wellington, you can explore lesser-known nature reserves and cultural museums.

What Makes These New Routes Stand Out

Each of Air New Zealand’s new routes is carefully designed to meet the growing demand for easy access to New Zealand and the Pacific Islands. But what sets them apart?

Queenstown ↔ Brisbane: The fact that this route is a seasonal, direct flight makes it highly attractive to adventure travelers who want to visit Queenstown’s ski resorts, bungy jumping locations, and vineyards without the hassle of long travel times.

Brisbane ↔ Auckland/Wellington/Christchurch: The increased capacity on these routes ensures that business and leisure travelers alike can find more flight options to these vibrant cities, making it easier to attend business meetings, festivals, and explore New Zealand’s natural beauty.

Christchurch ↔ Rarotonga: This route directly connects two beautiful destinations that are often overlooked. Rarotonga’s pristine beaches and crystal-clear waters make it a perfect getaway for those seeking tropical relaxation after exploring Christchurch’s gardens and mountain ranges.

Each of these routes allows travelers to experience New Zealand and the Pacific Islands in a more seamless and connected way, making these regions more accessible to global tourists.

Looking Ahead: More Routes and Future Expansion Plans

While Air New Zealand is making significant strides with its new routes, it’s clear that this expansion is only the beginning. The airline has indicated that it plans to continue expanding its network to meet the increasing demand for travel between Australia, New Zealand, and the Pacific Islands.

Future route expansions could include:

More seasonal or year-round routes connecting New Zealand with other Pacific Islands such as Tahiti, Fiji, and the Solomon Islands.

Additional connections between New Zealand and Asia, expanding options for tourists and business travelers who wish to visit both regions.

More flights to North America and Europe, offering travelers new, convenient ways to travel between these major continents.

Air New Zealand’s continued growth is an exciting development for both the aviation industry and tourism. As the world continues to recover from the global pandemic, Air New Zealand is setting the stage for a vibrant and interconnected future for international travel.

Conclusion: Why Air New Zealand’s New Routes Are a Game-Changer for Travel

Air New Zealand’s newly launched and enhanced routes are more than just a means of getting from one place to another. They represent new opportunities for travelers to explore the beautiful destinations of New Zealand and the Pacific Islands. From the thrill of Queenstown’s adventure tourism to the tranquil beaches of Rarotonga, these routes make travel easier, faster, and more enjoyable.

Whether you’re an adventure seeker, a culture lover, or someone looking to unwind in a tropical paradise, Air New Zealand’s new routes are designed to make these dream destinations more accessible. The added capacity on existing routes between Brisbane and Auckland, Wellington, and Christchurch further solidifies Air New Zealand’s position as the leading carrier in the region.

As the airline continues to expand, these new connections open the door to more amazing travel experiences, and we can only expect even more exciting developments in the future.

title: Russia completes first flight of first new domestically built Tu-214 at Kazan - Air Data News
description:
United Aircraft Corporation (UAC) has conducted the maiden flight of a newly built Tupolev Tu-214 from its manufacturing site in Kazan.
The flight marks the restart of the assembly entirely with domestic components, as part of ongoing efforts to replace foreign suppliers.
The maiden flight lasted 1 hour and 10 minutes.
The program has been extended to 2027 to accommodate delivery delays and modernization needs, underlining the Tu-214’s role in sustaining Russian domestic air transport.
It is produced at the Kazan Aviation Plant, while the Tu-204 is assembled in Ulyanovsk with a different door configuration.
text:
United Aircraft Corporation (UAC) has conducted the maiden flight of a newly built Tupolev Tu-214 from its manufacturing site in Kazan. The flight marks the restart of the assembly entirely with domestic components, as part of ongoing efforts to replace foreign suppliers.

The maiden flight lasted 1 hour and 10 minutes. The aircraft, which subsequently flew from Kazan to Minsk on 17 December, supports the Russian government’s import-substitution policy for the aviation sector.

This Tu-214 was initially reported as intended for Tatarstan-based UVT-Aero. However, UVT-Aero has stated it will focus on other aircraft types in coordination with the federal air transport regulator Rosaviatsia.

Follow us: WhatsApp | BlueSky | Google News | Instagram | LinkedIn | Facebook

UVT-Aero’s chief, Pyotr Trubaev, has said the carrier is examining the Ilyushin Il-114-300 and the Yakovlev SJ-100, both featuring significant domestic content. Aeroflot Group previously considered adding Tu-214s but is reportedly prioritizing MC-21s instead, said Flight Global.

State lessor GTLK committed to over 40 Tu-214s last year, reflecting broader fleet modernization efforts. Red Wings has recently taken delivery of Tu-214s, but these were older aircraft refurbished from storage rather than newly manufactured.

The Russian Ministry of Industry and Trade launched a restoration and airworthiness program for the Tu-204/214, Il-96, and An-124 in October 2022, initially targeting 12 aircraft for return to service by 2024.

The program has been extended to 2027 to accommodate delivery delays and modernization needs, underlining the Tu-214’s role in sustaining Russian domestic air transport.

The Tu-214, developed as a variant of the Tu-204 and first flown in 1996, features higher gross weight and additional fuel capacity compared to its predecessor. It is produced at the Kazan Aviation Plant, while the Tu-204 is assembled in Ulyanovsk with a different door configuration.

title: Porto vai receber corrida e acrobacias das aeronaves com o Air Invictus
description:
“O Air Invictus está alinhado com a “Estratégia 2035″, visando parcerias que estão a ser estabelecidas com países do mundo árabe e da Ásia, entre outros mercados”, é adiantado.
A Força Aérea Portuguesa é o parceiro oficial do Air Invictus e irá envolver diversas aeronaves como o KC 390, C 295, F 16 e os Super Tucanos.
O município será o centro das operações, com acrobacias, descolagens e aterragens, e batismos de voo.
A Força Aérea Portuguesa vai montar um foguetão em plena Alfândega, o que irá gerar a curiosidade de milhares de visitantes, entre os quais muitos oriundos das visitas de escolas.
Terminado o Air Invictus, a Faculdade de Economia da Universidade do Porto fará a avaliação da sua relevância económica, aferindo efeitos, impacto, emprego e outras variáveis.
text:
Outra novidade é o alargamento da iniciativa a Matosinhos e à Maia. “Esta marca e o novo conceito têm uma enorme capacidade para trazer ao Grande Porto um milhão de pessoas, das quais se espera que cerca de 300 mil sejam estrangeiras”, indica a empresa portuguesa Bravimaginação, responsável pela organização.

O certame está orçamentado em 7,5 milhões de euros, com uma parte a ser financiada por dinheiros públicos e outra por patrocinadores, mas a participação do público é gratuita. “O Air Invictus está alinhado com a “Estratégia 2035″, visando parcerias que estão a ser estabelecidas com países do mundo árabe e da Ásia, entre outros mercados”, é adiantado.

Os autarcas Luís Filipe Menezes e Pedro Duarte são dois dos principais entusiastas do regresso dos aviões ao Douro. Menezes falou do assunto durante a campanha e logo após a sua eleição para a presidência da autarquia gaiense, sempre com o objetivo acolher iniciativas a abranger as duas autarquias.

O programa engloba corrida de aviões, acrobacias aéreas, demonstrações militares pela Força Aérea Portuguesa, demonstrações policiais pelo Grupo de Operações Especiais/PSP, um festival de aeromodelismo, festivais de drones com a tentativa de bater o recorde da Europa na praia do Titan (Matosinhos); exposições de meios aéreos e militares com batismos de voo e festivais de música, entre outras iniciativas.

A Força Aérea Portuguesa é o parceiro oficial do Air Invictus e irá envolver diversas aeronaves como o KC 390, C 295, F 16 e os Super Tucanos. Haverá um F16 colocado na margem de Gaia e dois outros aviões do lado do Porto.

Um dos eventos associados é o “Eyes in the sky”, a primeira feira e “summit” da indústria de defesa aérea e aeroespacial, que irá mostrar na Alfândega do Porto, em 5000 m2 de exposição, “o que de melhor as empresas portuguesas estão a inovar, produzir e exportar para todo o mundo, e que trará ao nosso país visitantes, expositores, especialistas e cientistas para várias conferências”. Estará patente até ao dia 23 de junho. Haverá uma forte promoção internacional com ativações, campanhas na televisão e nas redes sociais, entre outras.

O regresso das aeronaves ao Douro “engloba uma componente de literacia aeronáutica para as escolas da região Norte, com visitas, palestras, contacto com pilotos e aviões, bem como batismos de voo, onde se pretende que os mais novos voltem a ganhar a paixão pelo espaço e pela aviação”, como explica a organização.

A organização refere que um forte dispositivo ficará estacionado no Aeródromo Vilar de Luz, na Maia, estando a ser equacionada a possibilidade de organizar um encontro mundial de “Chipmunks”, que comemoram 75 anos em 2026. Certa é a vinda dos “Warbirds”, aviões da segunda guerra mundial e que estarão em exposição no concelho maiato. O município será o centro das operações, com acrobacias, descolagens e aterragens, e batismos de voo. A organização espera que mais de 200 mil pessoas visitem o aeródromo no evento.

A Força Aérea Portuguesa vai montar um foguetão em plena Alfândega, o que irá gerar a curiosidade de milhares de visitantes, entre os quais muitos oriundos das visitas de escolas. Terminado o Air Invictus, a Faculdade de Economia da Universidade do Porto fará a avaliação da sua relevância económica, aferindo efeitos, impacto, emprego e outras variáveis. Está prevista a presença da imprensa estrangeira, bem como a transmissão nacional e internacional dos eventos.

title: IGL forms joint venture with HWT to develop compressed biogas and biofuel projects
description:
Indraprastha Gas Ltd (IGL) announced on Friday, December 19, that it has signed a joint venture agreement with Hindustan Waste Treatment Private Ltd (HWT) to establish compressed biogas (CBG) plants and other biofuel initiatives, reports CNBC TV18.
According to the agreement, the new joint venture will feature equal equity participation, with IGL and HWT each holding a 50% stake.
The board will initially include four directors, comprising two nominees from each partner, the company said in an exchange filing.
Revenue increased 2.8% to ₹4,022 crore from ₹3,913 crore, supported by stable demand.
Shares of Indraprastha Gas Ltd closed 1.03% lower at ₹194.01 on the NSE on Friday, December 19.
text:
Indraprastha Gas Ltd (IGL) announced on Friday, December 19, that it has signed a joint venture agreement with Hindustan Waste Treatment Private Ltd (HWT) to establish compressed biogas (CBG) plants and other biofuel initiatives, reports CNBC TV18.

According to the agreement, the new joint venture will feature equal equity participation, with IGL and HWT each holding a 50% stake. The board will initially include four directors, comprising two nominees from each partner, the company said in an exchange filing.

The collaboration is aimed at expanding IGL’s footprint in renewable energy and clean fuels, aligning with its long-term strategy to diversify its energy portfolio.

Financial Update: Q2 Results

Separately, IGL reported a 4.5% quarter-on-quarter rise in net profit to ₹372 crore for the second quarter, compared to ₹356 crore in the previous period. Revenue increased 2.8% to ₹4,022 crore from ₹3,913 crore, supported by stable demand.

Despite this, the company’s operational performance was affected by higher input costs. EBITDA fell 13.6% to ₹442 crore from ₹511.7 crore in the previous quarter, and the EBITDA margin tightened to 11% from 13.1% in Q1.

Shares of Indraprastha Gas Ltd closed 1.03% lower at ₹194.01 on the NSE on Friday, December 19.

title: Was 2025 the year that business retreated from net zero? | Energy industry | The Guardian
authors: Sarah Butler, Jasper Jolly, Gwyn Topham, Jillian Ambrose, Kalyeena Makortoff, Helena Horton, www.theguardian.com, jasper-jolly, jillian-ambrose, kalyeena-makortoff
description:
More companies have retreated from, or watered down, their pledges to cut carbon emissions, instead prioritising shareholder returns over climate action.
Earlier this year, the Conservative party leader, Kemi Badenoch, officially ditched net zero by 2050 as a Tory policy.
Labour was even forced to defend its net zero policy after an attack by its former leader, Tony Blair.
Traditional European carmakers were delighted, but manufacturers focused on electric cars said it would benefit Chinese rivals in the long term.
The UN-backed programme, launched in 2021, had committed firms to achieving net zero greenhouse-gas emissions by 2050.
text:
Almost a year since Donald Trump returned to the White House with a rallying cry to the fossil fuel industry to “drill baby, drill”, a backlash against net zero appears to be gathering momentum.

More companies have retreated from, or watered down, their pledges to cut carbon emissions, instead prioritising shareholder returns over climate action.

In the UK, the rise of Nigel Farage’s Reform UK has helped fracture the political consensus that had helped make Britain the first big economy to enshrine a commitment to cutting carbon emissions into law, in 2019. Earlier this year, the Conservative party leader, Kemi Badenoch, officially ditched net zero by 2050 as a Tory policy. Labour was even forced to defend its net zero policy after an attack by its former leader, Tony Blair.

Big players in retail and automotive this week became the latest businesses to weaken pledges – a retreat that threatens devastating consequences for the climate.

Running counter to this, many countries – notably China – have continued the march towards renewable power (which surpassed coal generation this year). Investment in clean energy, at $2tn a year, is now double that going into fossil fuels, according to the International Energy Agency.

Here we look at how important industries are treating net zero.

Cars and planes

For a few years after the pandemic, carmakers made bold promises that they would switch their factories to electric cars within a few years. Yet that momentum for change petered out by 2024 amid disappointing growth in battery car sales. In the US, EU and UK the lobbying campaign for weaker regulations has been intense – and successful.

Trump has torn up US electric vehicle subsidies – costing carmakers billions of dollars – and eased emissions rules to allow them to sell more cars with polluting petrol and diesel engines. This week, Ford said it would take a $19.5bn write-down and is scrapping several EV models.

The UK government said in April it would ease its zero-emission (ZEV) mandate. The rules still force carmakers to sell more electric cars each year, but new loopholes mean they can sell more hybrids, which combine a smaller battery with an internal combustion engine.

And the EU this week said that 10% of carmakers’ sales could be petrol or diesel after 2035, in a significant climbdown.

Traditional European carmakers were delighted, but manufacturers focused on electric cars said it would benefit Chinese rivals in the long term. Chris Heron, secretary general of E-Mobility Europe, a lobby group representing electric carmakers such as Tesla, Rivian and Polestar, said: “While China accelerates, Europe is hesitating, and hesitation is not a strategy.”

If the transition is stalling for ground transport, in the air things have not even started to take off. Airbus and Boeing, the global plane-making duopoly, have both made clear that their next planes will use gas turbine engines running on kerosene.

Airbus this year delayed plans to fly a plane using zero-emission “green” hydrogen by 2035, while supplies of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) – the solution of choice for many in aviation – remain nugatory compared with the vast size of global demand.

Neither did UK government policy on aviation inspire confidence that net zero remained front and centre. Two London airports, Gatwick and Luton, had significant expansion plans signed off by ministers, meaning tens of thousands of additional flights a year at each.

Meanwhile, the chancellor gave resounding backing for Heathrow expansion – despite previous official work making clear that only limited growth, allied with swift progress on decarbonisation, could make a third runway in any way compatible with 2050 targets.

Energy

For now, UK green energy investors remain buoyed up by Labour’s aim to create a virtually carbon-free electricity system by 2030, to stick with the net zero target and its pledge for no new North Sea drilling (with caveats).

However, the government’s green targets were dealt a blow earlier this year when the struggling Danish renewable energy company Ørsted cancelled plans for one of the UK’s largest offshore windfarms, Hornsea 4, off the Yorkshire coast.

Europe’s oil majors, including BP and Shell, have retreated from their climate commitments in favour of refocusing on oil and gas production. BP’s boss, Murray Auchincloss – who was dramatically ousted this week – said the company’s optimism in the energy transition had been “misplaced” and promised the company’s disillusioned shareholders that he would “fundamentally reset” BP’s strategy after its failed attempt to go green. His successor appears unlikely to change tack. Shell set out plans to pump more oil and gas while halving its green spending.

Banks and financial services

A swathe of financial firms have been watering down climate commitments following Trump’s return.

The most public sign of the U-turn has been the collapse of the Net-Zero Banking Alliance (NZBA) in October, after a wave of departures by US banks including JP Morgan, Citigroup and Goldman Sachs, as well as UK lenders Barclays and HSBC. The UN-backed programme, launched in 2021, had committed firms to achieving net zero greenhouse-gas emissions by 2050.

HSBC had months earlier announced it was delaying omportant parts of its climate goals by 20 years and watering down environmental targets in a new long-term bonus plan for its chief executive, Georges Elhedery, who took over last year.

Large investment houses such as Vanguard and BlackRock have also pulled membership from a sister group known as the Net Zero Asset Managers initiative, as the sector comes under pressure from Republican politicians.

Meanwhile, there are fears Labour could water down plans to require FTSE 100 firms and financial services to adopt “credible” climate transition plans, and disclosing their carbon footprints after City lobbying.

Retail

Retailers and their suppliers are among those taking a hard look at net zero ambitions amid rising costs.

Morrisons, the supermarket chain, this week delayed its ambition for net zero by 15 years until 2050, having previously set a deadline of 2035.

The British Retail Consortium industry body set out a roadmap to next zero by 2040 but its latest stocktake indicates the industry has only met the 2025 milestone on one measure – data on logistics. Only 38% of top suppliers have committed to meeting net zero.

Many retailers have reduced emissions in stores – with renewable energy and technology such as LED bulbs and electric vans – but most of their emissions are generated by their suppliers.

Even within stores the cost and complexity of shifting from gas to low-carbon heating , including the higher price of electricity compared with gas, has held back progress.

Local authorities

In the public sector, local councils have often taken net zero more seriously than even central government. Bristol was the first to declare a climate emergency in 2018 – a year before the government – and more than 300 other councils followed, with 90% setting net zero targets.

But as the political landscape has changed with the rise of Reform, some local authorities, led by those dominated by Farage’s party, are rolling back on net zero commitments. In Reform-led Lincolnshire, mayor Andrea Jenkyns has vowed to block any renewables projects in her jurisdiction (putting 12,000 jobs at risk if she succeeds), while Staffordshire county council, also Reform-controlled, has rescinded its declaration of a climate emergency.

Reform-controlled Durham council has scrapped its heat pump and solar panel scheme for government buildings, and energy efficiency upgrades such as insulation have been ditched in Kent, which is also under Reform.

Derbyshire county council disbanded its climate change, biodiversity and carbon reduction committee the week after Reform took power, and West Northamptonshire county council abandoned its net zero target.

title: Brazil forecasts sharp rise in sustainable aviation fuel use by 2027, Energy study shows
description:
Brazil is poised for a major shift toward sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) beginning in 2027, with consumption projected to reach 0.03 million tons of oil equivalent (Mtoe) by 2035, according to the Energy Research Company (EPE), reports bnamericas.
In its publication “Energy Demand of the Transport Sector,” part of the 2035 Ten-Year Energy Plan (PDE), the state-owned entity reports that SAF consumption will account for roughly 12% of domestic energy demand linked to passenger air transport by 2035.
EPE notes that 2027 marks the start of mandatory greenhouse gas (GHG) emission cuts for domestic operations by Brazilian airlines.
The PDE anticipates diesel oil B will remain the dominant fuel in the transport sector, with demand projected to reach 57.5 billion liters in 2035, growing 1.9% annually.
While electrification is gaining traction in specific areas such as last-mile freight, its share of total sector consumption is expected to remain limited through the end of the decade.
text:
Brazil is poised for a major shift toward sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) beginning in 2027, with consumption projected to reach 0.03 million tons of oil equivalent (Mtoe) by 2035, according to the Energy Research Company (EPE), reports bnamericas.

In its publication “Energy Demand of the Transport Sector,” part of the 2035 Ten-Year Energy Plan (PDE), the state-owned entity reports that SAF consumption will account for roughly 12% of domestic energy demand linked to passenger air transport by 2035.

The expected expansion is attributed to emission reduction targets under the Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (Corsia) and ProBioQAV, established by the federal Fuel of the Future program. EPE notes that 2027 marks the start of mandatory greenhouse gas (GHG) emission cuts for domestic operations by Brazilian airlines.

Petrobras and Acelen are among the companies advancing research and planning SAF production in the country. In contrast, Brasil Biofuels (BBF) has paused its plans as the company undergoes court-supervised reorganization following a filing earlier this year.

The PDE anticipates diesel oil B will remain the dominant fuel in the transport sector, with demand projected to reach 57.5 billion liters in 2035, growing 1.9% annually.

While electrification is gaining traction in specific areas such as last-mile freight, its share of total sector consumption is expected to remain limited through the end of the decade. For light vehicles, gasoline C use is projected to decline as hydrous ethanol gains ground, aided by improved vehicle efficiency and public transport expansion. Between 2023 and 2035, hydrous ethanol consumption is set to grow 5.3% annually, offsetting part of the demand for gasoline.

In maritime transport, emerging fuels—including biodiesel, liquefied natural gas (LNG), ammonia, hydrogen, and electricity—are projected to gain adoption, particularly after 2030.

Overall energy demand in the transportation sector is forecast to reach 115 Mtoe in 2035, driven primarily by road transport, which will account for 93% of total consumption. This rise is supported by expected GDP growth averaging 2.8% annually and increased population mobility.

Freight transport will continue to rely heavily on trucks, with the segment projected to grow 2.8% per year, fueled by agribusiness, industry, and construction.

Rail transport is set for notable expansion, with the network expected to increase by around 20% to reach 36.9 thousand kilometers by 2035, boosting sector activity by 5.5% annually.

Waterway freight is also expected to advance, growing 3.2% annually, backed by investments in vessels, shipyards, and ports, and strengthened by cabotage in oil logistics.

On the passenger side, individual vehicle use is projected to grow 2.4% per year, with registrations estimated to reach 3.8 million units by 2035.

The study indicates a gradual but steady rise in light-vehicle electrification, especially in major cities. By 2035, electrified vehicles are expected to represent about 6% of the national fleet, while flex-fuel vehicles will remain dominant at approximately 87%.

Public transportation is also set to expand, supported by investments under the Novo PAC program. Urban bus services are projected to grow 3.7% annually through 2035, while metro-rail systems are expected to increase by 3.6% per year, boosted by the anticipated launch of the Intermunicipal Train (TIM) and parts of the Intercities Train (TIC) in São Paulo.

title: Air France KLM Martinair Cargo and DHL renew partnership to boost sustainable aviation ...
description:
Air France KLM Martinair Cargo and DHL Global Forwarding have extended their strategic alliance to accelerate air freight decarbonisation, signing a new three-year framework agreement covering 2025 to 2027, reports Stat Trade Times.
The partnership aims to cut 35,000 tonnes of CO2-equivalent in 2025, marking the largest annual Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) collaboration Air France KLM Martinair Cargo has undertaken to date.
Since 2020, Air France KLM Martinair Cargo has focused on developing SAF programmes tailored to customers, while DHL has incorporated SAF into its GoGreen Plus service as part of its climate strategy.
GertJan Roelands, SVP Commercial at Air France KLM Martinair Cargo, said the agreement underscores ambition, mutual trust, and dedication to advancing SAF across the air freight value chain.
Henk Venema, EVP Global Airfreight at DHL Global Forwarding, said the framework demonstrates effective collaboration in decarbonisation and noted that predictability, scalability and transparency are crucial for sustainable aviation fuels to deliver meaningful impact.
text:
Air France KLM Martinair Cargo and DHL Global Forwarding have extended their strategic alliance to accelerate air freight decarbonisation, signing a new three-year framework agreement covering 2025 to 2027, reports Stat Trade Times.

The partnership aims to cut 35,000 tonnes of CO2-equivalent in 2025, marking the largest annual Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) collaboration Air France KLM Martinair Cargo has undertaken to date. Additional SAF volumes and emissions-reduction targets for 2026 and 2027 will be agreed upon as the partnership advances.

The renewed contract follows the previous three-year agreement, under which DHL achieved a reduction of 77,595 tonnes of CO2-equivalent between 2022 and 2024. That effort also helped customers meet science-based emissions-reduction goals.

Since 2020, Air France KLM Martinair Cargo has focused on developing SAF programmes tailored to customers, while DHL has incorporated SAF into its GoGreen Plus service as part of its climate strategy. The collaboration reflects shared expertise and a joint commitment to scaling low-carbon fuels.

Both companies emphasized that extending the partnership highlights the importance of long-term cooperation in accelerating the aviation sector’s transition to lower-carbon operations.

GertJan Roelands, SVP Commercial at Air France KLM Martinair Cargo, said the agreement underscores ambition, mutual trust, and dedication to advancing SAF across the air freight value chain.

Henk Venema, EVP Global Airfreight at DHL Global Forwarding, said the framework demonstrates effective collaboration in decarbonisation and noted that predictability, scalability and transparency are crucial for sustainable aviation fuels to deliver meaningful impact.

title: A Year in Supply Chain Stories: Looking Back on Q1
description:
Back when the US had a completely different administration in charge, the supply chain conversation began at the highest levels of government.
The US Quadrennial Supply Chain Review set the tone, revisiting national logistics priorities after years of pandemic-induced volatility.
Davos 2025: Key Supply Chain Sustainability Learnings The World Economic Forum’s 2025 sustainability sessions spotlighted a shared urgency: balancing growth with accountability.
Topics like emissions tracking, circular design and equitable sourcing took centre stage – particularly as investors demanded more transparent ESG metrics across global supply networks.
US Egg Prices Soar 36% It highlighted an issue which characterised the whole year – that supply chain resilience should perhaps be the most important focus for boardrooms.
text:
The first quarter of 2025 unfolded as a pivotal period for global supply chains – marked by political transitions, sustainability milestones and fresh challenges that tested resilience across industries.

Back when the US had a completely different administration in charge, the supply chain conversation began at the highest levels of government. The US Quadrennial Supply Chain Review set the tone, revisiting national logistics priorities after years of pandemic-induced volatility.

Inside the US Government's Landmark Supply Chain Review

Its release highlighted a renewed emphasis on technological modernisation and resource diversification – a bid to make the nation’s critical infrastructure more resilient and less dependent on single points of failure.

Meanwhile, in the consumer sphere, Amazon celebrated its billionth sustainable package delivery in the US – a landmark proving that circular logistics and sustainable packaging can coexist with high-volume e-commerce.

Inside Amazon's Billionth Sustainable US Package Delivery

The achievement illustrated the tangible effects of years of investment in renewable materials, optimised routing and smarter packaging analytics.

Beyond corporate success stories, Q1 also invited deeper reflection on evolving consumer behaviour.

One of the more unexpected logistics narratives came from the beverage sector, as demand for alcohol alternatives surged during “Dry January.” The rising preference among younger demographics for functional or alcohol-free drinks offered insight into how generational shifts are reshaping trade flows and inventory strategies in emerging markets.

Dry January & Rising Alcohol Alternative Demand

Supply chains that once optimised for volume and shelf appeal were now being forced to adapt to values-based consumption.

These individual developments echoed themes discussed on a global stage when business leaders, policymakers, and sustainability advocates convened in Davos.

Davos 2025: Key Supply Chain Sustainability Learnings

The World Economic Forum’s 2025 sustainability sessions spotlighted a shared urgency: balancing growth with accountability.

Topics like emissions tracking, circular design and equitable sourcing took centre stage – particularly as investors demanded more transparent ESG metrics across global supply networks.

In Washington, however, policy shifted again as the new US presidency reintroduced tariffs on select imports.

The move reignited concerns about manufacturing costs and sourcing diversification, particularly in sectors like automotive parts, electronics and textiles.

Trump Tariffs: What Businesses and Importers Need to Know

Analysts cautioned businesses to revisit their pricing models and reconfigure supply footprints – a reminder that political transitions often reshape cost structures overnight.

Consumers felt ripple effects on a more personal level. Even breakfast tables weren’t spared, as egg shortages and rising prices made headlines.

Supply snags in agriculture highlighted how fragile food logistics remain, despite advancements in demand forecasting and cold-chain management.

What Does it Take to Make Breakfast? US Egg Prices Soar 36%

It highlighted an issue which characterised the whole year – that supply chain resilience should perhaps be the most important focus for boardrooms.

title: SkyTeam announces The Aviation Challenge 2025 finalists - Aeronews Global
description:
SkyTeam has announced the finalists across 18 award categories in the fourth edition of The Aviation Challenge (TAC), its global initiative designed to help accelerate sustainable innovation and knowledge sharing in the aviation industry.
For the second year, The Aviation Challenge was opened to subsidiaries, affiliates and non-SkyTeam member airlines, reinforcing the program’s ambition to encourage change across the industry.
“Each year, The Aviation Challenge provides participating airlines with a platform to turn innovation into action and take practical steps toward sustainability.
Shortlisted initiatives include: national SAF roadmaps and supply chains, emissions reduction initiatives and transformation of aviation waste into micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs).
Shortlisted initiatives include: Regional knowledge-sharing events and university collaborations, as well as storytelling around emissions reduction and waste management programs.
text:
SkyTeam has announced the finalists across 18 award categories in the fourth edition of The Aviation Challenge (TAC), its global initiative designed to help accelerate sustainable innovation and knowledge sharing in the aviation industry.

Follow Aeronews on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, Bluesky and TikTok

The 2025 theme, ‘Impact,’ underscores the program’s commitment to driving tangible, measurable results.

TAC welcomed 22 airline participants to its fourth competition, challenging them to develop and implement innovative solutions to advance sustainability in aviation. For the second year, The Aviation Challenge was opened to subsidiaries, affiliates and non-SkyTeam member airlines, reinforcing the program’s ambition to encourage change across the industry.

Between 26 September and 26 October 2025, participating airlines completed more than 80 showcase flights—the highest number to date. The showcase flight serves as a practical demonstration of innovative solutions that help enable sustainability progress, while the overall Challenge design encourages ongoing, organization-wide adoption of solutions. Collectively, participants submitted 224 solutions and initiatives for awards. Aligned with the ‘Impact’ theme, TAC 2025 emphasized measurable achievements in reducing carbon emissions, improving energy efficiency and optimizing waste management.

“Each year, The Aviation Challenge provides participating airlines with a platform to turn innovation into action and take practical steps toward sustainability. This fourth edition has been especially inspiring, with participants demonstrating determination, ingenuity and initiative throughout the Challenge. Their commitment was reflected in a record number of showcase flights. We congratulate all the airlines on their efforts to help shape a more responsible future for aviation,” said Patrick Roux, SkyTeam CEO.

All entries were rigorously assessed against a comprehensive set of technical criteria by a panel of aviation and sustainability experts, including the Netherlands Aerospace Centre (NLR) and PA Consulting. Finalists have been recognized across four main categories, each with subcategories acknowledging their achievements.

Highlights include:

Direct Impact Awards

This category recognizes effective solutions across key operational areas, including flight operations, ground operations, cargo, maintenance, catering and inflight products.

Shortlisted initiatives include: use of artificial intelligence (AI) to improve payload accuracy or climb optimization, replacement of single-use plastics in catering and optimization of potable water loading at outstations.

Organizational Transformation Awards

This category honors airlines that have made notable advancements in organizational capabilities across sustainability training,

Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), procurement and data

Shortlisted initiatives include: adoption and scaling of SAF, training programs to build sustainability awareness and use of data to improve operational efficiency.

Leadership Awards

This category acknowledges airlines that have excelled in leadership, teamwork and collaboration. Within this focus area, TAC participants will select the winners for three subcategories through peer voting.

Shortlisted initiatives include: national SAF roadmaps and supply chains, emissions reduction initiatives and transformation of aviation waste into micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs).

Inspiration Awards

This category recognizes the best overall showcase flight, as well as distinction in storytelling and knowledge sharing.

Shortlisted initiatives include: Regional knowledge-sharing events and university collaborations, as well as storytelling around emissions reduction and waste management programs.

Finalist submissions are now being reviewed by a jury of 8 international experts in the fields of aviation and sustainability. The winners in each category will be announced at an awards event to be held in Copenhagen, Denmark from 20-22 January 2026, hosted by SAS.

title: Does Alaska Air's Weaker Outlook and 2026 Expansion Plan Reshape the Bull Case for ALK?
description:

title: United's 737 MAX 10s: 300+ Hours Flown And Still No Passengers - Simple Flying
description:
What makes this situation especially complex is the fact that many of these aircraft have already been built, with, for example, 26 widebodies from the 777X family having been produced to date.
Away from the 777X family, this is also something that has been observed on the narrowbody side of things, with data from Aviation Flights showing that United's undelivered Boeing 737 MAX 10s have amassed over 300 hours.
The oldest of these is N27751, which, having first flown in June 2021, is now 4.5 years old.
This month has also seen two other United Airlines-bound Boeing 737 MAX 10 aircraft take to the skies, with N27752 in the air as recently as December 17 when it flew from Boeing Field to Eugene, Oregon, and back.
United Airlines & The Boeing 737 MAX 10 United Airlines hasn't had the easiest of times with regard to its order for the Boeing 737 MAX 10, with the carrier having to deal with years of delays as various factors have hindered the certification process of the largest variant of the next-generation narrowbody.
text:
It's no secret that several of Boeing's latest models of commercial aircraft are going to enter service many years behind schedule, with delays plaguing the certification of both the narrowbody 737 MAX 7 and 10 models and the widebody 777X family. What makes this situation especially complex is the fact that many of these aircraft have already been built, with, for example, 26 widebodies from the 777X family having been produced to date.

However, until these aircraft are certified for entry into commercial service, they cannot be delivered to their customers, but they do still need to take to the skies on a test basis every now and then to keep them fresh. Away from the 777X family, this is also something that has been observed on the narrowbody side of things, with data from Aviation Flights showing that United's undelivered Boeing 737 MAX 10s have amassed over 300 hours.

Already Racking Up The Hours

According to present fleet data made available by ch-aviation, United Airlines has a grand total of 167 Boeing 737 MAX 10 jets in its current order book, with those that have already been produced clocking in at an average age of 2.6 years old. The oldest of these is N27751, which, having first flown in June 2021, is now 4.5 years old. Its most recent test flight, a circular journey from Boeing Field (BFI), took place on December 16.

This month has also seen two other United Airlines-bound Boeing 737 MAX 10 aircraft take to the skies, with N27752 in the air as recently as December 17 when it flew from Boeing Field to Eugene, Oregon, and back. Meanwhile, N27753 made a circular test flight from Boeing Field on December 4. Needless to say, plenty more flight hours will be racked up before these jets can join United, which said back in 2017 that:

"The 737 MAX 10 will enable us to continue using larger and more efficient aircraft within our domestic network and better meet the needs of our customers today and into the future."

One Of The Aircraft Has Been Used As A Boeing ecoDemonstrator

Arguably the most notable use of a Boeing 737 MAX 10 jet that is destined for United Airlines has been the deployment of N27602 as part of the US planemaker's 'ecoDemonstrator' research program. This was announced by Boeing in 2023, and saw the manufacturer team up with NASA to conduct tests.

As part of this initiative, the special aircraft, which, as seen in the picture embedded above, wore a colorful striped livery in this role, operated test flights powered by Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF). When in the air for this purpose, it was trailed by a Douglas DC-8 from NASA to measure its emissions.

This allowed researchers to gather data concerning the differing emissions levels produced by SAF compared to conventional jet fuel, as well as the differences in contrail ice particles. Boeing added that "the researchers' aim [was] to understand how advanced fuels, engine combustor designs, and other technologies may reduce atmospheric warming," given that "some research has suggested certain contrails can trap heat in the atmosphere."

United Airlines & The Boeing 737 MAX 10

United Airlines hasn't had the easiest of times with regard to its order for the Boeing 737 MAX 10, with the carrier having to deal with years of delays as various factors have hindered the certification process of the largest variant of the next-generation narrowbody. Indeed, in 2017, when the carrier first announced its order for 100 examples of the MAX 10 at the Paris Air Show, United was expecting to begin taking delivery of the type in late 2020.

title: Southwest Airlines CEO Salary in 2025 - Aviation A2Z
authors: Atharva Khadilkar, Kevin Derby, Natalia Shelley
description:
Advertisement Who is Southwest Airlines CEO Bob Jordan?
ALSO READ: Delta Air Lines CEO Salary in 2025 Southwest Airlines CEO Bob Jordan Salary in 2025 As of 2025, Bob Jordan’s annual compensation package reflects both the scale of Southwest’s operations and its performance-based executive pay system.
Southwest Airlines Plans for 2025 As 2025 unfolds, Southwest is undertaking several initiatives aimed at enhancing operational stability and passenger experience.
Bottom Line Bob Jordan’s salary as CEO of Southwest Airlines mirrors the balance between performance, accountability, and culture that defines the company.
Southwest Airlines CEO Salary FAQs Stay tuned with us.
text:
Southwest Airlines (WN) stands as one of America’s most recognisable low-cost carriers, with an identity built around friendly service, simple fares, and a deep domestic network. Founded in 1967 and based in Dallas, Texas, the airline has grown from a small Texas-based operator to one of the largest carriers in the world by passengers carried.

Even as the aviation industry faced turbulence in recent years, Southwest maintained a solid reputation for efficiency and cost control. Its no-frills model, focus on employee culture, and strong brand loyalty have been key in keeping it competitive. But guiding such a massive operation through economic shifts, operational challenges, and changing travel habits requires steady leadership, and that’s where CEO Bob Jordan plays a crucial role.

Below is a closer look at Bob Jordan, his professional background, and his salary package as of 2025.

Advertisement

Who is Southwest Airlines CEO Bob Jordan?

Robert “Bob” Jordan became Chief Executive Officer of Southwest Airlines in February 2022, succeeding long-time CEO Gary Kelly. His journey with the airline spans more than three decades, making him one of the most deeply rooted leaders in Southwest’s history.

Born in Oklahoma, Jordan earned a degree in Computer Science from Texas A&M University. He joined Southwest in 1988 as a programmer analyst, but quickly demonstrated an ability to connect people, systems, and operations.

Over the years, he held key roles in technology, corporate strategy, and revenue management, shaping many of Southwest’s modern efficiencies.

In the 2000s, Jordan became Vice President of Technology before moving into network planning and later heading commercial operations.

He played a major role in the integration of AirTran Airways after Southwest’s acquisition in 2011, a complex merger that expanded the carrier’s reach and strengthened its domestic network.

Before assuming the top job, Jordan served as Executive Vice President of Corporate Services and later as Executive Vice President and Chief Commercial Officer.

Known for his collaborative, down-to-earth leadership style, he often emphasises Southwest’s people-first culture, seeing employees as the backbone of its customer experience.

Under his leadership, the company has been focused on technology upgrades, improved reliability, and sustainable growth.

ALSO READ: Delta Air Lines CEO Salary in 2025

Southwest Airlines CEO Bob Jordan Salary in 2025

As of 2025, Bob Jordan’s annual compensation package reflects both the scale of Southwest’s operations and its performance-based executive pay system.

His pay structure comprises a base salary, short-term bonuses, long-term equity incentives, and retirement-related contributions.

Here’s an approximate breakdown based on 2024 filings and current market adjustments:

Base salary: around $675,000 per year

Annual cash incentive (bonus): up to $2.3 million, depending on company and personal performance metrics

Long-term equity awards: roughly $4.8 million, primarily in restricted stock units and performance shares

Other benefits and compensation: approximately $200,000, covering retirement contributions, insurance, and miscellaneous perks

This takes his total target compensation to around $8 million annually, though actual payouts fluctuate based on performance and market valuation.

In the 2024-25 financial year, Jordan’s total realised pay was around $6.8 million, slightly below target levels due to operational disruptions and financial volatility in the post-pandemic period.

ALSO READ: United Airlines CEO Scott Kirby Salary in 2025

Peer Comparison

Bob Jordan’s compensation stands at the lower-middle range when compared to his counterparts at major U.S. airlines.

At Delta Air Lines, CEO Ed Bastian earned roughly $13 million in total compensation, supported by a much larger long-haul and international network.

Robert Isom, CEO of American Airlines, received around $11.3 million, while Scott Kirby of United Airlines earned approximately $12.5 million.

Jordan’s total package of roughly $8 million places him below these peers, consistent with Southwest’s lower-cost, domestic-focused business model. However, the percentage of his pay tied to performance remains among the highest in the sector.

This difference also reflects strategic philosophy: while legacy carriers compete aggressively on global reach and premium products, Southwest’s leadership is compensated more for maintaining reliability, profitability, and employee morale within a single-brand structure.

Despite the smaller top-line number, Jordan’s influence within U.S. aviation is widely recognised, particularly as he steers a carrier known for its people-driven ethos rather than corporate hierarchy.

Southwest Airlines Plans for 2025

As 2025 unfolds, Southwest is undertaking several initiatives aimed at enhancing operational stability and passenger experience. Following the severe winter disruption of 2022, the airline accelerated its technology modernisation and scheduling upgrades to avoid similar issues.

Fleet renewal continues to be a priority, with new Boeing 737 MAX aircraft joining the fleet to improve fuel efficiency and reduce maintenance costs. The company expects deliveries to stabilise as Boeing resolves production challenges, enabling smoother capacity planning.

Financially, Southwest anticipates steady revenue growth driven by strong domestic demand, improved business travel, and additional routes in underserved mid-size markets. The airline has also reintroduced a more refined loyalty programme and is expanding its digital platforms for easier booking and trip management.

Workforce investment remains central to Jordan’s leadership, with higher pay agreements for crew, training programmes for ground staff, and a renewed push to sustain Southwest’s historically positive labour relations.

Sustainability targets for 2030 and beyond are being revisited, focusing on increased use of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), more efficient flight operations, and ongoing partnerships with fuel technology providers.

Overall, 2025 marks a phase of recalibration for the airline, aiming to blend the low-cost simplicity Southwest is known for with the digital agility expected in modern aviation.

Bottom Line

Bob Jordan’s salary as CEO of Southwest Airlines mirrors the balance between performance, accountability, and culture that defines the company.

While his pay may fall below the giants of the U.S. airline industry, the long-term incentive weighting ensures his rewards depend heavily on measurable success.

Leading a workforce of over 70,000 people and maintaining one of the industry’s best employee satisfaction records is no small feat. Jordan’s leadership through turbulence, both operational and economic, highlights why compensation alone doesn’t tell the whole story.

For 2025, Southwest continues to focus on reliability, sustainable growth and technology-driven improvements, and Jordan remains firmly at the helm of one of the most admired brands in commercial aviation.

Southwest Airlines CEO Salary FAQs

Stay tuned with us. Further, follow us on social media for the latest updates.

title: Solar aviation fuel: Unique Swiss Air deal starts in 2023 - PVKnowhow
description:
The deal secures a decade-long supply of solar aviation fuel, positioning SWISS as the world’s first airline to commit to using this innovative, low-carbon fuel.
Solar Fuel to Reduce Carbon Emissions in Aviation The core of this agreement is solar fuel, a synthetic paraffinic kerosene produced using concentrated solar energy.
This sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) is designed to significantly cut carbon emissions by replacing traditional fossil-based jet fuel.
First Commercial Production of Solar Aviation Fuel Synhelion is set to begin the world’s first commercial production of solar fuel at its facility in Jülich, Germany.
Future of Solar Aviation Fuel in Aviation The collaboration between SWISS and Synhelion is expected to pave the way for the broader adoption of solar fuel across the aviation industry.
text:
Swiss Air Lines to Purchase Solar Aviation Fuel in Long-Term Deal with Synhelion

In a groundbreaking move for sustainable aviation, Swiss International Air Lines (SWISS) has signed a strategic, long-term offtake agreement with the clean energy company Synhelion. The deal secures a decade-long supply of solar aviation fuel, positioning SWISS as the world’s first airline to commit to using this innovative, low-carbon fuel. This partnership marks a significant step toward decarbonizing the aviation sector and highlights a practical application of advanced solar technology.

Solar Fuel to Reduce Carbon Emissions in Aviation

The core of this agreement is solar fuel, a synthetic paraffinic kerosene produced using concentrated solar energy. This sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) is designed to significantly cut carbon emissions by replacing traditional fossil-based jet fuel. The process is a remarkable feat of engineering; it uses concentrated solar heat to convert carbon dioxide and water into syngas, which is then processed into liquid fuel.

This innovative manufacturing process creates a “drop-in” fuel, meaning it is fully compatible with existing aircraft and fueling infrastructure. Unlike biofuels, it doesn’t compete with agricultural land for raw materials, instead using captured CO2. This initiative aligns perfectly with Switzerland’s ambitious solar goals, demonstrating how the country’s commitment to solar power extends beyond electricity generation into complex industrial applications.

First Commercial Production of Solar Aviation Fuel

Synhelion is set to begin the world’s first commercial production of solar fuel at its facility in Jülich, Germany. For German residents and renewable energy enthusiasts, this places the country at the forefront of a new era in sustainable fuel production. SWISS plans to begin using the solar kerosene from 2025, marking a pivotal moment for the airline industry.

The establishment of such a facility requires a deep understanding of the basics of solar panel manufacturing and the sophisticated manufacturing machines needed to harness solar thermal energy. This solar fuel is poised to be a game-changer, providing a scalable, sustainable alternative that supports the aviation industry’s goal of achieving net-zero emissions by 2050.

Long-Term Agreement for Solar Aviation Fuel

The 10-year agreement provides Synhelion with the planning security needed to scale up production and provides SWISS with a stable supply to gradually integrate solar fuel into its operations. This long-term commitment is crucial for capital-intensive projects, reflecting the importance of impressive solar project financing to bring new green technologies to market.

This strategic partnership is a key component of SWISS’s broader environmental strategy. By setting a benchmark for the industry, the airline hopes to encourage other carriers to adopt similar sustainability practices and invest in cleaner fuel sources. The financial planning behind such a large-scale project is complex, often requiring detailed analyses similar to the financial modeling for a Swiss solar factory.

Future of Solar Aviation Fuel in Aviation

The collaboration between SWISS and Synhelion is expected to pave the way for the broader adoption of solar fuel across the aviation industry. As production capacity increases and the plant cost breakdown becomes more efficient with scale, more airlines may follow SWISS’s pioneering lead. This initiative is a powerful example of how national energy goals, like the Swiss solar energy targets, can drive innovation with global impact.

Solar fuel has the potential to revolutionize air travel by providing a cleaner, more sustainable energy source. Overcoming logistical challenges, much like those addressed in strategies for landlocked solar manufacturing, will be key to its widespread success. SWISS’s commitment demonstrates a proactive approach to tackling climate change, setting a positive example for the industry and contributing to a greener future for aviation.

If you are interested in the technical and business aspects of bringing solar technologies to life, from initial concept to full-scale production, consider exploring our free e-course on solar panel manufacturing.

title: Nanocellulose-Templated Aluminosilicate Supported Ni-Based Mono- and Bimetallic ... - SSRN
authors: Jawa Timur, Indonesia Jaksa Agung Suprapto, Malang Malang, Kec. Sukolilo, Kota SBY, Asikin-Mijan, Meyga  Evi Ferama, Ingelia  Yuan, Khawiyatur  Riv’ah, Trias  Alzatory
description:
Abstract The growing demand for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) necessitates efficient catalytic routes for convertion of sustainable feedstock into jet-fuel-range hydrocarbons under mild reaction conditions.
In this work, robust mesoporous aluminosilicate (MA) was synthesized using nanocellulose as template in sol-gel and hydrothermal methods.
Impregnation with Ni and bimetallic NiCo, NiFe, NiMo catalysts on MA enhanced jet fuel hydrocarbon from pyrolysis of used coconut oil at 360oC.
NiMo/MA exhibited the 97% highest conversion of oil to produce 62% liquid yield and 48% hydrocarbon.
NiMo/MA enhanced selectively to C8–C16 hydrocarbons (58.77%), matching the typical jet-fuel fraction.
text:
Abstract

The growing demand for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) necessitates efficient catalytic routes for convertion of sustainable feedstock into jet-fuel-range hydrocarbons under mild reaction conditions. In this work, robust mesoporous aluminosilicate (MA) was synthesized using nanocellulose as template in sol-gel and hydrothermal methods. Impregnation with Ni and bimetallic NiCo, NiFe, NiMo catalysts on MA enhanced jet fuel hydrocarbon from pyrolysis of used coconut oil at 360oC. Metal nanoparticles partially blocked the mesopores, but increased Lewis acidity, and metal–support interactions. H2-TPR revealed enhanced reducibility and the formation of NiO–MoOx, while XPS verified the predominance of Ni2+ and Mo6+ species. NiMo/MA exhibited the 97% highest conversion of oil to produce 62% liquid yield and 48% hydrocarbon. NiMo/MA enhanced selectively to C8–C16 hydrocarbons (58.77%), matching the typical jet-fuel fraction. The superior performance is attributed to the synergistic between Ni-Mo to provide a balanced Lewis/Brønsted acidity in the mesoporous aluminosilicate. Nanocellulose as a hard template produced robust mesoporous channel in aluminosilicate-supported NiMo as an efficient and sustainable catalyst for decentralized SAF production from waste lipids.
